newsitem.title: UK: Aframax tankers fall on high tonnage, few cargoes.
newsitem.headline: Aframax tankers fall on high tonnage, few cargoes.

text.p: European 80,000 tonne (Aframax) dirty tanker rates fell on Tuesday on an oversupply of vessels and few cargoes, brokers said.
Middle East very large crude carriers also remained depressed, but business was brisk and some brokers said they expected rates to rise.
In the inter-U.K./Cont sector, Aframaxes fell to W92.5 from W97.5 on Monday after remaining steady at W100 for most of last week.
In the Mediterranean, Aframaxes also dipped to W107.5 from W110, and are now some 17.5 points down from the high of last week, brokers said.
"There is plentiful tonnage and few cargoes," said a North Sea broker. "Aframaxes in the Med are also weaker, so where is the inspiration to come from?"
The cross-Med 130,000 tonne (Suezmax) market, meanwhile, was quiet, with the rate steady for now at W92.5.
Mideast VLCCs remained below the W50 level, except to Japan where they managed to fetch around W50/52.5. Mideast/Singapore and westward VLCCs were fixed around W47.5.
However, the market was active, with some nine or 10 vessels fixed on Monday plus a number of private deals, and brokers said rates were unlikely to stay in the doldrums for much longer.
"I can't see VLCCs staying where they are. They have got to move up on such a lot of activity. There will be a turning point soon, if not this week, next week," one said.
West Africa/U.S. Gulf VLCCs were steady at W67.5, with Suezmaxes around W92.5, while North Sea/U.S. VLCCs were assessed at about W65 in quiet trade.
In the fuel oil sector, 25,000 tonnes remained depressed at W185 inter-U.K./Cont but edged up to W195/200 in the Med on rising demand and less prompt tonnage, brokers said.

Caribs/upcoast 70,000 tonne crude cargoes dipped to W220 from W225, but remain historically extremely high -- almost 70 points above the average for last year, according to New York-based Rigos Chartering Inc.
Fuel oil 50,000 tonnes remained soft at W162.5. "Unless natural gas stays high, fuel oil will be based on opportune trade...and will stay down this summer," a U.S. broker said.
